title: First Submarine Telegraph Cable (Dover–Calais)
summary: The earliest operational undersea telegraph linked England and France.
facts: Gutta-percha insulation protected copper in seawater.
Demonstrated feasibility of submarine links.

crossSection.svg: <circle cx='50' cy='50' r='45' fill='#b87333'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='40' fill='none' stroke='#000' stroke-width='2'/>

trivia.question: What insulated early submarine conductors?
trivia.fact: Gutta-percha was the standard underwater insulator for decades.

title: First Transatlantic Telegraph Cable
summary: Intercontinental telegraphy worked—briefly—proving the concept despite rapid signal loss.
facts: Queen Victoria exchanged messages with President Buchanan.
High voltages degraded the cable quickly.

crossSection.svg: <circle cx='50' cy='50' r='45' fill='#b87333'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='40' fill='none' stroke='#000' stroke-width='2'/>

trivia.question: Why did the 1858 cable fail after weeks?
trivia.fact: High test voltages damaged the insulation, dooming the first attempt.

title: Durable Transatlantic Telegraph Cable
summary: A successful, reliable Atlantic link ushered in the true era of global telegraphy.
facts: Improved manufacture and operating practices fixed early issues.
Traffic soared across the Atlantic.

crossSection.svg: <circle cx='50' cy='50' r='45' fill='#b87333'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='40' fill='none' stroke='#000' stroke-width='2'/>

trivia.question: What changed between 1858 and 1866?
trivia.fact: Gentler electrical practice and better materials made the 1866 cable endure.

title: First Outdoor Two‑Way Telephone Call
summary: Bell and Watson’s outdoor call demonstrated voice over wire networks.
facts: Set the stage for rapid telephone expansion.
Early lines used simple iron/copper pairs.

crossSection.svg: <circle cx='50' cy='50' r='45' fill='#b87333'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='40' fill='none' stroke='#000' stroke-width='2'/>

trivia.question: What improvement over telegraphy did telephone enable?
trivia.fact: Continuous analog waveforms carried intelligible speech.

title: Twisted Pair Technique
summary: Pair twisting reduced crosstalk, becoming the default for telephony and later data.
facts: Twists average out external magnetic fields.
Foundation for modern Ethernet over copper.

crossSection.svg: <rect x='10' y='30' width='80' height='40' fill='#ffa500'/><circle cx='30' cy='50' r='3' fill='#b87333'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='3' fill='#b87333'/><circle cx='70' cy='50' r='3' fill='#b87333'/>

trivia.question: Why are wires twisted in pairs?
trivia.fact: Twisting cancels induced noise, preserving signal integrity.

title: Coaxial Cable Patented
summary: Espenschied & Affel’s patent enabled broadband, shielded transmission lines.
facts: Became backbone for early TV and long‑haul telephony.
Excellent RF performance vs. open wire.

crossSection.svg: <circle cx='50' cy='50' r='45' fill='#c0c0c0'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='35' fill='#ffa500'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='25' fill='#b87333'/>

trivia.question: What does 'coaxial' mean?
trivia.fact: Inner and outer conductors share the same axis.

title: Early Long‑Haul Coax Trials
summary: Prototype coax systems ran between major cities, validating high‑bandwidth trunking.
facts: Enabled multi‑channel telephony and TV relays.
Proved repeater spacing and loss models.

crossSection.svg: <circle cx='50' cy='50' r='45' fill='#c0c0c0'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='35' fill='#ffa500'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='25' fill='#b87333'/>

trivia.question: What did the trials primarily validate?
trivia.fact: Trials established practical performance for long‑distance coax trunks.

title: TAT‑1: First Transatlantic Telephone Cable
summary: Coaxial TAT‑1 provided 35 initial voice circuits across the Atlantic.
facts: Expanded to more channels with improved multiplexing.
Ran between Scotland and Newfoundland.

crossSection.svg: <circle cx='50' cy='50' r='45' fill='#c0c0c0'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='35' fill='#ffa500'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='25' fill='#b87333'/>

trivia.question: What medium carried TAT‑1 traffic?
trivia.fact: TAT‑1 used pressurized, loaded coaxial cables and repeaters.

title: Kao & Hockham Propose Low‑Loss Fiber
summary: Theoretical groundwork that optical fiber could deliver telecom‑grade losses.
facts: <20 dB/km loss target focused research.
Kao received Nobel Prize in 2009.

crossSection.svg: <circle cx='50' cy='50' r='45' fill='#ffffff'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='35' fill='#87ceeb'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='25' fill='#ffffff'/>

trivia.question: What loss target unlocked fiber telecom?
trivia.fact: The 20 dB/km target made fiber practical for telecom.

title: First Commercial Fiber‑Optic Link
summary: Early metro fiber deployment proved practicality of optical communications.
facts: Attractive for EMI immunity and bandwidth.
Led to rapid metro rollouts.

crossSection.svg: <circle cx='50' cy='50' r='45' fill='#ffffff'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='35' fill='#87ceeb'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='25' fill='#ffffff'/>

trivia.question: What feature helped fiber win in cities?
trivia.fact: EMI immunity and bandwidth density were decisive.

title: TAT‑8: First Transatlantic Fiber
summary: TAT‑8 carried digital signals across the Atlantic at hundreds of Mbit/s.
facts: Heralded the end of coax subsea for new builds.
Optical amplifiers soon multiplied capacity.

crossSection.svg: <circle cx='50' cy='50' r='45' fill='#ffffff'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='35' fill='#87ceeb'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='25' fill='#ffffff'/>

trivia.question: What did TAT‑8 replace for new subsea builds?
trivia.fact: Fiber displaced coax subsea for capacity and reliability.

title: 10BASE‑T Ethernet (802.3i)
summary: Brought Ethernet to twisted pair with star topologies and RJ45 connectors.
facts: Catalyzed structured cabling in offices.
10 Mb/s became the ubiquitous baseline.

crossSection.svg: <rect x='10' y='30' width='80' height='40' fill='#ffa500'/><circle cx='30' cy='50' r='3' fill='#b87333'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='3' fill='#b87333'/><circle cx='70' cy='50' r='3' fill='#b87333'/>

trivia.question: 10BASE‑T primarily uses which medium?
trivia.fact: The shift from coax to twisted pair simplified LANs.

title: TIA/EIA‑568 & Category 5
summary: Structured cabling standards aligned performance and pinouts across buildings.
facts: Enabled multi‑vendor interoperability.
Set the stage for Fast/Gigabit Ethernet.

crossSection.svg: <rect x='10' y='30' width='80' height='40' fill='#ffa500'/><circle cx='30' cy='50' r='3' fill='#b87333'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='3' fill='#b87333'/><circle cx='70' cy='50' r='3' fill='#b87333'/>

trivia.question: What did ANSI/TIA‑568 standardize?
trivia.fact: The spec unified telecom rooms and channel performance.

title: Fast Ethernet (100BASE‑TX)
summary: 100 Mb/s over Cat5 wiring became mainstream for LANs.
facts: Backwards compatibility eased upgrades.
Full‑duplex switches replaced hubs.

crossSection.svg: <rect x='10' y='30' width='80' height='40' fill='#ffa500'/><circle cx='30' cy='50' r='3' fill='#b87333'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='3' fill='#b87333'/><circle cx='70' cy='50' r='3' fill='#b87333'/>

trivia.question: What cable category enabled 100BASE‑TX widely?
trivia.fact: Category 5 met the requirements for 100 Mb/s signaling.

title: USB 1.0 Released
summary: USB unified PC peripherals with up to 12 Mb/s data rates.
facts: Supported 1.5 and 12 Mb/s modes.
Replaced serial/parallel ports for many devices.

crossSection.svg: <rect x='20' y='40' width='60' height='20' fill='#000000'/><rect x='25' y='45' width='50' height='10' fill='#ffd700'/>

trivia.question: Top USB 1.0 speed?
trivia.fact: USB 1.x topped out at 12 Mb/s before USB 2.0’s 480 Mb/s.

title: DOCSIS 1.0 Cable Internet
summary: Standardized cable‑modem Internet service over HFC networks.
facts: Enabled mass‑market broadband in the late 1990s.
Uses upstream/downstream RF channels.

crossSection.svg: <circle cx='50' cy='50' r='45' fill='#c0c0c0'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='35' fill='#ffa500'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='25' fill='#b87333'/>

trivia.question: DOCSIS runs over which plant?
trivia.fact: Hybrid Fiber‑Coax architectures carry RF data & TV.

title: HDMI 1.0
summary: Single‑cable digital audio/video interface for consumer electronics.
facts: Carries video, multi‑channel audio, and CEC control.
Replaced many analog connectors.

crossSection.svg: <rect x='20' y='40' width='60' height='20' fill='#000000'/><rect x='25' y='45' width='50' height='10' fill='#ffd700'/>

trivia.question: HDMI 1.0 first targeted?
trivia.fact: HDMI simplified home A/V with one cable.

title: USB 3.0 (SuperSpeed)
summary: Raised USB throughput to 5 Gb/s and added full‑duplex lanes.
facts: New extra pins; backward compatible with USB 2.0.
Enabled faster storage and peripherals.

crossSection.svg: <rect x='20' y='40' width='60' height='20' fill='#000000'/><rect x='25' y='45' width='50' height='10' fill='#ffd700'/>

trivia.question: Headline speed of USB 3.0?
trivia.fact: SuperSpeed at 5 Gb/s was a 10× jump over USB 2.0.

title: USB‑C Connector Published
summary: Reversible, compact connector supporting data, display, and high‑power delivery.
facts: Supports Alternate Modes like DisplayPort.
Symmetric design removes plug orientation.

crossSection.svg: <rect x='20' y='40' width='60' height='20' fill='#000000'/><rect x='25' y='45' width='50' height='10' fill='#ffd700'/>

trivia.question: Why is USB‑C reversible?
trivia.fact: Symmetric contacts let the plug work either way up.

title: IEEE 802.3bs (200/400GbE)
summary: Ethernet standard for 200 and 400 Gb/s over fiber.
facts: Enabled 400G DC/backbone deployments.
Often uses PAM4 optics.

crossSection.svg: <circle cx='50' cy='50' r='45' fill='#ffffff'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='35' fill='#87ceeb'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='25' fill='#ffffff'/>

trivia.question: Common modulation for 400G optics?
trivia.fact: PAM4 encodes two bits per symbol for higher throughput.

title: 800G Coherent Optics Era
summary: Coherent 800G moves from trials to early production in subsea & terrestrial backbones.
facts: Delivers spectral efficiency for long‑haul links.
Often pluggable (QSFP‑DD/CFP2‑DCO).

crossSection.svg: <circle cx='50' cy='50' r='45' fill='#ffffff'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='35' fill='#87ceeb'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='25' fill='#ffffff'/>

trivia.question: What enables long‑haul 800G?
trivia.fact: Coherent receivers with DSP correct impairments.

title: EU USB‑C Charging Mandate
summary: EU law standardizes USB‑C as the common charging port for many devices.
facts: Aims to reduce e‑waste and consumer friction.
Accelerates global USB‑C adoption.

crossSection.svg: <rect x='20' y='40' width='60' height='20' fill='#000000'/><rect x='25' y='45' width='50' height='10' fill='#ffd700'/>

trivia.question: One goal of the EU mandate?
trivia.fact: Standardizing on USB‑C reduces duplicate chargers and cables.

title: Self-Healing Cables: Wires That Fix Themselves
summary: Cutting-edge materials enable cables to autonomously repair damage and extend lifespan.
keyAdvancement: Autonomous repair of insulation and conductors
facts: Microcapsules release healing agents when cracks form in insulation
Some materials can restore electrical conductivity after damage
Potential to reduce maintenance costs in hard-to-reach installations

crossSection.svg: <circle cx='50' cy='50' r='45' fill='#b87333'/><circle cx='50' cy='50' r='40' fill='none' stroke='#000' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/>

trivia.question: What triggers self-healing in microcapsule-based materials?
trivia.fact: When a crack forms, it ruptures microcapsules, releasing healing agents that flow into and seal the damage.

trivia.question: Which industry was an early adopter of self-healing cable technology?
trivia.fact: NASA and other aerospace organizations were among the first to explore self-healing wire insulation for spacecraft and aircraft, where repairs are extremely difficult.

trivia.question: What is a key advantage of dynamic bond-based self-healing materials?
options: They don't require any external trigger
trivia.fact: Dynamic bond-based materials can heal the same spot multiple times, making them more durable than single-use microcapsule systems.
